BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Further increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate to strong. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are being formed by the northwesterly wind will become increasingly prone to triggering. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1800 m.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular at intermediate and high altitudes and along the border with Switzerland.
Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the wind slabs will increase in size from late morning. The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area in particular along the border with Switzerland. The fresh snow and also in particular the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming over a wide area represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow to below approximately 1400 m: In some regions increase in danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially above approximately 2000 m and.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The new snow was deposited on bare ground over a wide area, in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at intermediate and high altitudes, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area some new snow to below approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow of the last three days represents the main danger. This snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. Below approximately 2200 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. Especially at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The fresh wind slabs are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. The covering of new snow is moist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released easily in particular on very steep shady slopes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects and at elevated altitudes. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for meticulous route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Sunday the wind has been moderate to strong adjacent to ridgelines in particular in the regions of the north that are exposed to the foehn wind and along the border with Switzerland. Here sometimes deep wind slabs formed. These are lying on weak layers in particular on very steep north, northeast and northwest facing slopes.
The soft wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

On steep slopes and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain natural dry avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen since Thursday. 30 to 50 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Will be deposited on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of natural avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases.
New snow and wind slabs can over a wide area be released by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially above approximately 2200 m and.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2200 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area moderate northwesterly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
In localities where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible in the regions with a lot of snow.
In particular on steep slopes natural avalanches are possible.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular above approximately 1800 m and.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs are prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mostly sunny.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from southerly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular at elevated altitudes. The wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on southwest to north to east facing aspects. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation such avalanche prone locations are more widespread and exist in all aspects. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.

As a consequence of solar radiation individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs have increased in size moderately in the last few days. They are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack will be quite moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs require caution. The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. As a consequence of solar radiation individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases on west to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. Somewhat older wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Avalanche prone locations are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation such avalanche prone locations are a little more prevalent. Avalanches can reach medium size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

On steep grassy slopes and below approximately 2600 m individual gliding avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

On extreme sunny slopes loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small, in the event of solar radiation in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow.
Monday: The wind will be moderate. Some snow will fall from the afternoon in the north.

The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to east facing aspects. No distinct weak layers exist in the bottom section of the snowpack. The solar radiation will give rise to slight moistening of the snowpack on sunny slopes.

Intermediate altitudes: The snowpack will be moist. At low altitude only a little snow is now lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will bring about a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. Individual loose snow avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More recent wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. In isolated cases the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1900 m. The covering of new snow is moist. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The sometimes strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. As the precipitation eases individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence on steep north, northeast and northwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: On shady slopes and on wind-loaded slopes the likelihood of dry avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger of wet and gliding avalanches in all regions is within the uppermost range of danger level. The new snow of the last three days represents the main danger. The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at high altitude. Below approximately 2200 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. Especially at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area in some localities up to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 1900 m. The covering of new snow is moist. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular in regions exposed to heavier precipitation and in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is greater.
As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation individual natural loose snow slides are possible, even medium-sized ones. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places in particular on very steep shady slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. More snow than expected has fallen in particular in the Primiero- Pale di S. Martino and in neighbouring regions. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers on shady slopes above the tree line. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. As the precipitation eases individual loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.
The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular above approximately 1800 m and.
In particular on steep slopes natural avalanches are possible.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mostly sunny.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Sunday the wind has been strong at times in particular in the regions that are exposed to the foehn wind and in neighbouring regions. Soft wind slabs formed. These are lying on unfavourable layers in particular on very steep north, northeast and northwest facing slopes.
The soft wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

On steep slopes and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain natural dry avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen since Thursday. 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. In many places new snow is being deposited on bare ground (--), in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Will be deposited on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of natural avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are small but in some cases prone to triggering. Somewhat older wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes. Above approximately 2400 m such avalanche prone locations are a little more prevalent and the danger is level 2 (moderate). Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

On steep grassy slopes and below approximately 2600 m individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

On extremely steep sunny slopes small loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of solar radiation this applies.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a strong southerly wind, mostly small wind slabs formed by Saturday. 5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Sunday.

Monday: The wind will be moderate. Some snow will fall from the afternoon in the north.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers on northwest to north to east facing aspects. No distinct weak layers exist in the bottom section of the snowpack. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack on sunny slopes.
Intermediate altitudes: The snowpack will be moist. At low altitude only a little snow is now lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. As a consequence of solar radiation loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1700 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack above approximately 1800 m.
